content: How can I help you today?

I've been having a really hard time sleeping lately. My mind just doesn’t seem to stop racing when I lie down at night. There’s a lot going on at work, and it’s stressing me out—so much that I can’t seem to shut it off. My partner thought I should try talking to someone, so here I am.

That sounds really overwhelming—being unable to sleep because of racing thoughts and work stress can feel exhausting. It's understandable why your partner suggested talking to someone. What are your thoughts about starting this conversation or exploring what’s been happening?

To be honest, I'm not exactly sure how much this will help, but I’m willing to give it a try. Work has just been so uncertain, and I keep worrying that I'm going to lose my job. I’m constantly thinking about how I'm going to take care of my family if that happens. It’s been a lot to carry.

It sounds like the uncertainty at work and the worry about providing for your family are weighing heavily on you. That’s a lot to navigate, and it makes sense that it’s affecting your sleep and adding stress. It says a lot about your commitment to your loved ones that you're here and open to talking—where would you like to begin?

I’m not really sure where to start, honestly. Mostly, I keep stressing about whether I'm doing enough at work or if I'm going to get blindsided by layoffs. It feels like every little mistake could be the one that puts me on the chopping block, and then my family would be in trouble. It’s just this constant loop running through my head.

That constant, looping fear about job security and its impact on your family sounds exhausting to live with. It seems like you’re carrying a lot of responsibility and putting pressure on yourself to try and protect your family from uncertainty. How do you usually handle stress like this, or has it felt different this time?

Honestly, I don’t think I’ve ever felt this level of stress before. Usually, I’d just power through or try to distract myself, but this feels different—like I can’t turn it off. No matter what I do, the thoughts keep coming back, and I just feel stuck in my head.

That feeling of being stuck in your head and unable to find relief sounds really tough—it’s no wonder you're finding this experience so different and challenging. You’ve tried powering through and distracting yourself before, which shows you’re resourceful when dealing with stress, but it seems like this particular situation is asking something different of you. What do you think might help, or what feels like the next step in trying to cope with this?

I'm honestly not sure what might help. I just want to stop feeling like I'm drowning in my own thoughts all the time. Maybe figuring out how to deal with the stress at work would help, but I don't know where to even start with that.

Feeling like you're drowning in your thoughts, with no clear way forward, sounds really overwhelming. It's understandable that addressing the work stress might feel like a good place to start, but it can be challenging when you’re unsure where to begin. What’s one small thing you think might give you even a bit of relief, or help you approach this differently? Or if it helps, would you like support in exploring that together?
I’m really not sure. I guess I’ve never thought about small ways to relieve stress—they feel kind of pointless when the big stuff feels so overwhelming. Maybe you could help me figure something out?

It’s completely okay to feel like small steps might not make a difference when the big challenges feel so heavy. Exploring ways to approach or ease the stress together sounds like a good start. Would it be helpful to look at some daily habits, like sleep patterns, physical activity, or moments of calm during your day? Or we can focus on ways to address your thoughts directly—whatever feels most relevant for you.

It’s completely okay to feel like small steps might not make a difference when the big challenges feel so heavy. Exploring ways to approach or ease the stress together sounds like a good start. Would it be helpful to look at some daily habits, like sleep patterns, physical activity, or moments of calm during your day? Or we can focus on ways to address your thoughts directly—whatever feels most relevant for you.

The racing thoughts are clearly making sleep really difficult, and your stress feels like it's creeping into every part of your day. How do you feel about exploring sleep patterns or physical activity to see if they connect with what’s been going on? If you'd like, the sensing agent tool can provide step count, sleep duration, or resting heart rate data—sometimes reflecting on these signals could offer some insight into moments for potential change. Would that be helpful for you, or would you prefer to focus above on managing thoughts directly?

I think focusing on the thoughts might make the most sense since that’s really what’s keeping me up at night. I feel like I can’t really get on top of everything going on in my head—it’s just nonstop, especially when I’m trying to fall asleep.

It makes sense to focus on the thoughts since they’ve been constant and are interfering with sleep. Those racing thoughts at night sound relentless, and dealing with them might feel like an uphill battle. What do you think contributes to the thoughts spiraling when you’re lying in bed, or what have you noticed about how they start?

When I try to fall asleep, it’s like everything I’ve been pushing aside during the day comes rushing in. I start replaying conversations from work, stressing over tasks I think I could’ve done better, and imagining worst-case scenarios about losing my job. It feels like my brain is stuck in overdrive, and I can’t seem to turn it off.

That surge of thoughts at night—replaying work conversations, doubting tasks, and imagining worst-case scenarios—sounds really overwhelming. It’s like everything you’ve been holding back during the day gets louder as soon as you lie down. It’s tough when your mind feels stuck in overdrive just when you’re hoping for rest. Have you ever tried ways to calm your mind before bed, or does this feel like something new for you to navigate?

It’s exhausting to deal with that constant mental chatter, especially when it’s hard to escape. I haven’t tried much to calm my mind before bed—I usually just lay there, waiting for sleep to come, but it doesn’t. I don’t even know where to start when it comes to calming my mind—do you have any suggestions?

Thank you for sharing that—it sounds like waiting for sleep to come hasn’t been giving you much relief, and feeling unsure about where to start is completely understandable. There are some strategies that could help ease that mental chatter, such as grounding techniques, relaxation exercises, or creating a bedtime routine. Would you like to explore these ideas together to see what might resonate with you?
